But otherwise, I think it's more important to strengthen the economy in their home countries and to make sure that the people there are doing well. So even a Spaniard who has lived in Germany for a long time will be able to speak German very well at some point, yes? And of course he will probably still be very close to home, but he will have integrated very well, yes? All other cultural groups, it is really difficult, for example, I have cases near Wiener Neustadt in Lower Austria, just two days ago I spoke with a young mother who has a child, a 6-year-old in preschool, kindergarten, and there are now three Austrians out of 25 children, all the rest are foreigners. Yes. And there it is; there is the critical mass. This is an expression from physics, but I would also use it in this context, yes? It always depends on the quantity. cleaned_comment: So first of all, on the subject of confession. This is what I wanted to say earlier. By saying, do we have to adapt perfectly to the country we arrive from or can we have a balance? In France, it is very different from Spain, it is very different from most of the other European countries, we have a requirement of secularism, that is to say that we do not have... there is a religious practice, Christian, historical, that is still active but in place of secularism above in the sense that religious worship is of the private place. So, we cannot, for example, hold this discourse, to say that the immigrants who come to France must respect a Christian tradition, for example. It is something that we can say, but in effect, it does not appear in schools, except in private schools. But we don't face it. So for me, the answer to the problem, to the possible problem posed by immigrants of Muslim faith, it passes by there in fact, secularism is what allows to respect the differences of each one. Well, that is perhaps also my conditions but when you speak about adapting, I personally, I adapt rather little to the French traditions, therefore and yet, I am French, I will not leave me. So that's it. So this story of saying that you have to confront a certain culture; you have to enter a form that... I'm finishing because now I have... Personally, I don't think that would be the right answer, because there are too many differences and I don't think that one country equals one culture in fact. That's it, personally. After that, on the story of the impoverishment of the countries of origin, and to say that we can't do anything, it's their choice, I think that it's not completely true. We have a mainly Muslim immigration, mainly from Algeria. It is important to know that these are colonized countries and I am not saying that they all come from there, but the same goes for African immigration. Today, there are multinational companies based in the West, in France in particular, which work there, and which do not necessarily participate in maintaining an economic fabric there. That is to say that in a certain way, if we really wanted to make political decisions about people in the countries of origin, there are ways to do so, through politics and economics. And indeed, as you said, people take incredible risks, they put their lives at risk, they put the lives of their families at risk, to immigrate in conditions, well, they do not do it from dictatorship, but it is not only a choice, I think in fact. So, these are extremely complex questions and I am not an angelist either, I am not at all in favor of a mass legalization of all immigrants, etc. The problems are too complicated in terms of the number of immigrants and the number of people who are not legal. The problems are too complicated in terms of - especially in financing our pensions and social assistance - actually today, we don't necessarily ask whether people work to immigrate. But in any case that's what I wanted to say.
speech: [01 :22] Donc d’abord sur le sujet de la confession. C’est ce que je voulais dire tout à l’heure. En France, c’est très différent qu’avec  l’Espagne, c’est très différent qu’avec la plupart des autre pays européens, nous avons une exigence de la laïcité, c'est-à-dire que nous n’avons pas… il y a une pratique religieuse, chrétienne, historique, qui est toujours active mais en place de la laïcité au dessus dans le sens où le culte religieux est de l’endroit privé. Et effectivement, comme vous disiez, des gens prennent des risques incroyables quand même, ils mettent leur vie en péril, il mettent la vie, des fois, de leur famille en péril, pour immigrer dans des conditions, bon, il ne le font de dictature, mais ce n’est pas seulement un choix, je pense en fait. Then it will become clear that we already have approaches - I'm not a specialist, I'm waiting for the experts - we have approaches to minimum standards, for asylum accommodations, for example. And that must provide the basis. I could imagine, without being a politician now, that you start there, just as you have to introduce social status. We don't have a discourse on that. And that is the task of the politicians in the EU, unfortunately our parliament has no right of initiative, and to bring the 27 states under one hat, with Berlusconi and the boat people, these are the real problems, we must not talk them down. So there are enormous problems, but I think, to round it off again, as with internal security, domestic policy, Schengen Agreement, border control, only the external borders are controlled, the national borders are not controlled. From Poland he can drive through the Czech Republic to Germany, from Spain he can drive through France, but where is the border? They know less about that in the south, between Belarus and Poland and between Ukraine and Poland. There we have sharp borders with German policemen, German know-how, German money. Why shouldn't German money go in at some point, for example in the partner country, which I would like to support, a selected country, where I contribute to it, and if I only make a big social experiment, I take a former German colony, invest a few million there and see if I can help them to the extent that the pressure to migrate there - the reason for migration - becomes less. Wir haben Fortschritte auf gesamteuropäischer Ebene mit verpflichtenden Gesetzen bei der Polizei Europol. Wir sind ja verpflichtet, dem Grundgesetz und dem europäischen Grundrechten auch und gerade was die zu uns gekommenen – seien sie legal oder illegal, oder aus Afrika oder aus Asien – haben wir Grundverpflichtungen von unseren Werten her. Und das muss die Basis geben. Ich könnte mir vorstellen, ohne jetzt ein Politiker zu sein, dass man da anfängt, so wie man Sozialstatus einführen muss. Da haben wir keinen Diskurs. Von Polen kann er ja über die Tschechei fahren n ach Deutschland, von Spanien kann er durch Frankreich fahren, aber wo ist die Grenze? Das sollte die starke EU insgesamt machen. Ausgewählte Partnerländer, wo überhaupt Chancen bestehen, weil es funktionsfähige Regierungen, Strukturen gibt, das sind Voraussetzungen; Rechtssysteme, einklagbar. Ihr haltet eure Verträge, bitte. Sogar Berlusconi versucht es. Ich bin [… …], es interessiert mich halt politisch. Was hat Berlusconi gemach, was hat die spanische Politik gemacht, was hat die gemacht mit Tunesien? Ein Abkommen. cleaned_comment: Yes, we have to be careful when we comment, sometimes we interpret things a little bit, but have to be a little bit humble about it I guess. I noticed one thing in particular now for example. Selective immigration of businessmen and employers. Certainly we've seen that at first glance - it's a little bit shocking to me. Why should business leaders be leaders in immigration? Well, focusing on those who have qualification that are scarce to the EU, those should be admitted selectively? I, for example, would say that immigration should be led by employers already, because people who immigrate basically just want a job. If we have a job, we will automatically have an income, if we have an income, then we are just satisfied. After all, that's what we want. Self-reliance. Immigration should then be regulated or controlled, but the whole thing must already be monitored or controlled by the employers as well. Because they will provide the appropriate jobs. That's what I wanted to point out here in particular. But we should not read too much into it here. If we want strongly regulated immigration, that does not mean that we are no longer human. Yes? We can still want this and still be humane about it and still be a little bit altruistic.

cleaned_comment: so at this point I would like to contradict my two previous speakers in a way. Just because the language is the same, even if it's helpful, that's not a guarantee that there will be integration. There are other countries that have much more practice. Look at the United States, they've had two populations for 200 years, one colored, one white, and if you look closely, one Hispanic. And they are far from being a homogeneous people. And we are not going to become a homogeneous Europe, whether we have an EU parliament or not. And it's not bad at all that there are Greek rites and customs in Greece and German customs in Germany. But it becomes difficult when you expect people to live there who don't share that. Then it becomes more and more complicated. There are certainly people who accept this and want to have rights and duties, the right to live here, and therefore also the duty to integrate. But just - it is not the normal case. You can't see that. We have only 2.4 percent Turks in Germany and yet the Turks are, so to speak, the dominant group of foreigners.

cleaned_comment: What we see here, in fact, is that this story of the common denominator, Europe, why we arrive at 27, is unfortunately or fortunately, that is in principle his ideological point of view, it is something else. On the other values, on the other questions, the question has not been asked - do the 27 countries of Europe have common values? The question has not been asked in fact. I am talking about the enlargements, I am talking about the hard core, let's say the countries that came together after the Second World War. There, there were really - and still, it was for economic decisions, it was to group together the metal and coal trade, so we see that we were not really in the (...) either. And for immigration it's the same thing, that is to say, we look at immigration from an economic point of view, we are confronted with that. Then, on how to manage illegal immigration: the question I ask myself is when should an immigration be illegal and when is it legal? That is to say, can an immigrant, who entered illegally, access by the work ticket or by the marriage ticket or something like that, a legal status or not. I believe that this is the question that must be answered. If it's no, there's no choice, it means that by building a wall, in fact, we talked during the break, Brigitte, about the border between Mexico and America, so well, afterwards, we have to see in effect how it happens. This is a physical wall, not a symbolic one. It's a physical wall with curves, everything is metric, etc. Either we accept to manage it on a case-by-case basis and say, here are people coming in and people will come in. That's what I say too. If we let the goods in, we let the people in. Of course, either we cut completely, but we cut everywhere. You don't cut down on humans, you also cut down on goods, you also cut down on trade, etc. And if we agree to say that people come in anyway, legally or illegally, we have to find the means to say when we will give them a blue card or the equivalent. So in France, at this point, we are confronted with policies to flush out, let's say, illegal immigrants, which causes a lot of friction. Well, me personally, I am extremely shocked by certain things, in the way they happen, at the same time, I don't say that the solutions, they have to be found, but we have to always bring the thing back, that is, belonging to [...], we say that the illegal immigrants don't have the right to be on the territory anymore. It means that we drive them, it means that we don't let them in. So this is a question that can be managed at the European level. The fact of saying that we can't let them in effectively, if everyone, as Alberto said, if we let the local politicians, I mean, when I say local... if we let the national politicians answer this question. Unfortunately, they are going to answer in, (... ...) to say, in two, three, four, five years, depending on the chances they have. So, they will give electoral answers. Europe has this chance to force itself to consensus in fact. And consensus is complicated, but at the same time, in my opinion, it forces us to make more intelligent decisions. Although smoother, although perhaps more radical, but in any case, we are obliged to think about it together. That's the difficulty, but that's the chance.
speech: [02 :23] Ce qu’on voit là en fait surtout c’est que cette histoire de dénominateur commun l’Europe, pourquoi on arrive à 27, c’est malheureusement ou heureusement, ça c’est en principe son point de vue d’idéologie, c’est autre chose. Mais le dénominateur commun il est uniquement économique en fait. Pourquoi on arrive à 27 ? C’est parce que 27 peuvent faire du commerce ensemble. Sur les autres valeurs, sur les autres questions, la question s’est pas posée sur – est-ce que les 27 pays d’Europe ont des valeurs communes ? La question se n’est pas posée en fait. Je parle des élargissements, je parle du noyau dure, on va dire des pays qui se sont regroupés après la seconde guerre mondiale. Où là il y avait  véritablement – et encore, c’était pour des décisions économiques, c’était pour regrouper le commerce de métaux et du charbon, donc on voit qu’on n’était pas vraiment dans les (…) non plus. Et pour l’immigration c’est la même chose, c'est-à-dire que, donc, on regarde l’immigration d’un point de vue économique, on est confronté à ça. Alors après sur comment gérer l’immigration illégale : Moi, la question que je me pose c’est à partir de quand une immigration devrait illégal et à quand elle est légale ? C'est-à-dire, est-ce que un immigré, entré illégalement, peut accéder par le billet du travail ou par le billet de mariage ou quelque chose comme ça, un statut de légalité ou non. Je crois que c’est ça la question à quelle il faut répondre. Si c’est non, il y a pas le choix, ça veut dire que en construire un mur, en faite, on a parlé pendant la pause, Brigitte, de la frontière entre Mexique et l’Amérique, alors bon, après, il faut voir dans l’effet comment ça se passe. Et voilà, ça c’est un mur physique, ce n’est pas un mur symbolique. C’est un mur physique avec des rondeurs, tout est métrique, etc. Soit on accepte de gérer au coup par coup de dire voilà des gens rentrent et des gens rentreront. C’est ce que je dis aussi. Si on laisse rentrer les marchandises, on laisse rentrer les gens. Certes que soit on coupe complètement, mais on coupe partout. On ne coupe pas aux humains, on coupe aussi aux marchandises, on coupe aussi aux échanges commerce, etc. Et si on accepte de dire que les gens de toute façon rentrent, légalement ou illégalement, il faut trouver les moyens ensuite, de dire à partir de quel moment, on leur donne une carte bleu ou équivalente. Alors en France, à ce moment là, on est confronté à des politiques pour débusquer, on va dire, les immigrés illégaux, qui occasionnent pas mal de friction. Bon, moi personnellement, je suis extrêmement choquer de certains choses, de manière comme ils se passent, en même temps, je ne dis pas que les solutions, ils doivent se trouver, mais il faut toujours ramener le truc, c'est-à-dire, appartenant[ ?], on dit que les immigrés illégaux n’ont plus le droit d’être sur le territoire. Ça veut dire qu’on leur conduit, ça veut dire qu’on ne les laisse pas entrer. Donc ça c’est une question qui peut se gérer au niveau européen. Le fait de dire qu’on ne peut pas les laisser rentrer effectivement, si chacun, comme disait Alberto, si on laisse les politiques locaux, on veut dire, quand je dis locaux.. si on laisse les politiques nationaux répondre à cette question là. Malheureusement, ils vont répondre en, (… …) de dire, dans deux, trois, quatre, cinq ans, suivant les chances qu’ils ont. Donc, ils vont apporter des réponses électoralistes. L’Europe a cette chance de pouvoir se forcer elle-même à du consensus en fait. Et le consensus c’est compliquer mais en même temps ça oblige à mon avis à prendre des décisions plus intelligentes. Quoique plus lisse, quoique peut-être plus radical, mais en tout cas, on est obligé d’y réfléchir à plusieurs. C’est la difficulté, mais c’est la chance. [06 :17]

cleaned_comment: As far as the definition of legal and illegal immigration is concerned, legal immigration is very well defined: these are people who, before their immigration, have already had an authorization to enter; students, scientists, family reunions when a member of the family already lives in the country. These are the three main groups of legal immigrants or green cards, etc. People who already have a job, a university degree, a monthly salary, etc. These are the legal ones. Illegals, illegals, are all those who do not belong to these groups, so people who entered the country, for example by a tourist visa in a completely legal way but who did not leave the country after the expiration of their visa. So these are people who are staying in the country illegally. This is a definition that has been proposed by the European Union and has been adopted by most countries. Just to explain what it is.

Ça ce sont les trois grands groupes de l’immigration légale ou alors là, soit des green cards, etc. des personnes qui ont déjà un emploi, un diplôme d’université, un traitement mensuel, etc. ça ce sont les légaux. Les illégaux, les clandestins, ce sont tous ceux qui n’appartiennent pas à ces groupes, donc des personnes qui sont entré dans le pays, par exemple par un visa touristique de manière tout-à-fait légale mais qui n’ont plus quitté le pays après l’échéance de leur visa. Donc ce sont des personnes qui séjournent alors de manière illégale dans ce pays. C’est une définition qui a été proposée par l’Union Européenne et qui a été reprise par la plupart des pays. Just pour expliquer de quoi qu’il s’agit. [40 :30]

cleaned_comment: So, what I could understand when I worked in these two organizations, one of which was rather the reception of immigrants, the other rather in the control of immigration. What I understand is that today the states are still free to set their own rules for their own territory. These rules are more important than the rules set by the EU, which is more concerned with the movement of immigration within the borders. What I could see is that in France, for example, there was a period when people arriving in France were required to sign a contract that included learning the French language. To facilitate integration. Today we have radically changed our approach, that is to say that we ask that people who wish to immigrate to France be able to prove in their own country that they are French. So in fact there are movements of agents of the French state that are in countries that are identified as countries for seeing immigration applications and it is in these countries, when we control for example the language, so that is a first criterion but of course there is another criterion that was posed more recently by the French government which is to identify the professional skills. It's a little bit like the euro question, which effectively means choosing between [...] the immigration population, which is what we need in France today. But there is another phenomenon that is very important, which has been the subject of discussion but which at the same time is laid down as a basic principle by the Geneva Convention. It is the right to family reunification, the fact that a person who has arrived in France has the right to bring his family. So this right is laid down in the Convention on Human Rights. And this is a right that is currently unassailable and that is difficult to reconcile with migration policies in the framework that states would like to make of this migration policy. Here is the reading of what I could see and understand.

cleaned_comment: During the break, I thought about what we were saying earlier and I think that already, between men and women, we don't have the same sense of sensitivity regarding immigration. Having said that, I listened to what was said just now, and I asked myself two questions, which are fundamental questions; when we are dealing with the problem of immigration, first of all, what do the immigrants expect from us and what do we expect from them? So, there were some answers already, we expect them to be hard-working, to be courageous, to be honest, to be respectful, okay? And so that's what we expect from them. And what do they expect from us? Well, they can expect certain things. We're talking about legal immigration. They can wait to have a good job, they can wait to find themselves with that good job in a peaceful country, they can also wait, if they already have family, in the ten countries, to be able to find, join their family. Okay, they have all the right reasons to want to come here. But there are always counterparts and it is true that we cannot tolerate all of them and I think that we must put a B on this and say that immigration works well if it is controlled. If we don't do anything, because by wanting to integrate all these people, by wanting to get all the misery in the world, we create frustrated people in our countries, we create people who may be unemployed, they may think - rightly or wrongly - that it is the immigrant who has taken a potential job.
